curriculumTitle: The Digital Mind: The Neuroscience, Algorithms, and Analytics of Social Media (Expanded Version)
overview: This interdisciplinary STEM curriculum bridges the gap between adolescent social media usage and academic STEM principles. Students explore the neuroscience behind addiction (Biology), the logic behind content feeds (Computer Science/Math), and the statistical impact of screen time on mental health (Data Analysis). The curriculum aligns with Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) and federal TRIO objectives.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I (understanding of variables and linear functions) is recommended. Basic familiarity with spreadsheet software (Google Sheets/Excel) and common social media platforms.

fieldTrips.name: UT Dallas Center for BrainHealth
fieldTrips.description: A guided visit to the BrainHealth Imaging Center to observe fMRI technology and discuss neuroplasticity and the brain's reward systems with researchers.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Reinforces Module 1 and 2 concepts regarding dopamine pathways, addiction, and the biological impact of repetitive digital stimuli.

activities.title: Module 1: The Dopamine Loop (Part 1) - Neuroscience & Simulation
activities.description: Students explore the biology of the VTA (Ventral Tegmental Area) and conduct a dice-rolling simulation to mimic the 'Variable Ratio Schedule' used in app design.
learningObjectives: Identify the role of neurotransmitters (dopamine) in the brain's reward system.
Simulate 'Intermittent Variable Rewards' using probability tools.
teks: (Biology) 10.A: Describe the interactions that occur among systems that perform functions of regulation... and defense in animals.
(Psychology) 6.C: Analyze the relationship between conditioning and behavior modification.
texasStemStandards: STEM Content Knowledge: Students demonstrate understanding of neurochemistry concepts.

brief: 1. Mini-Lecture (10 min): Dopamine and the Reward Pathway.
2. Setup (5 min): Pair students (User vs. Algorithm).
3. Round 1 (10 min): Low reward probability (roll 6 to win).
4. Round 2 (10 min): High reward probability (roll 4, 5, 6 to win).
5. Cleanup: Save data sheets for Module 2.
detailed: Introduction (10 mins): Explain the biological purpose of dopamine (survival/seeking) vs. the modern application (scrolling). Define 'Variable Ratio Schedule' (slot machine logic).
Setup (5 mins): Assign partners. Distribute dice and tokens. Explain that the 'Algorithm' student controls the rewards.
Simulation Round 1 (10 mins): The 'User' attempts to refresh their feed every 5 seconds. The 'Algorithm' rolls. Only a 6 yields a token. Students record the exact time of each reward.
Simulation Round 2 (10 mins): Increase the odds. Now, rolling a 4, 5, or 6 yields a token. Students record data. Save all data sheets for the next module.

brief: 1. Listen to the briefing on how your brain processes rewards.
2. Partner up: One person is the 'Phone', one is the 'User'.
3. Simulation 1: 'Phone' rolls dice. 'User' only gets a token on a 6.
4. Simulation 2: 'Phone' rolls dice. 'User' gets a token on 4, 5, or 6.
5. Record every win on your data sheet.
detailed: Step 1: The Setup. You are simulating a 'Skinner Box'. The User wants a reward (token); the Phone controls when they get it.
Step 2: Low Dopamine Round. The 'User' asks for a refresh every 5 seconds. The 'Phone' rolls. If it is 1-5, say 'No Notification'. If it is 6, give a token.
Step 3: High Dopamine Round. Repeat the process, but now the User wins on a 4, 5, or 6.
Step 4: Data Logging. Accurate recording is crucial. Mark down exactly which 'scroll attempt' resulted in a token. You will need this for the next class.

trioCompliance.justification: Qualifies as Laboratory Science instruction. Students are replicating a behavioral psychology experiment regarding neurochemistry.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Instruction in laboratory science.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.453 - Materials and supplies costs, including costs of computing devices.

stemConnections.science: Neuroscience: Synaptic transmission and the reward pathway.

activities.title: Module 2: The Dopamine Loop (Part 2) - Graphing Addiction
activities.description: Using data generated in Module 1, students graph the stimulus/response frequency to visualize how unpredictability drives behavior.
learningObjectives: Graph data related to stimulus and response frequencies.
Analyze the difference between fixed and variable ratio reinforcement.
teks: (Math Models) 1.A: Use mathematical models to approximate and predict patterns in data.
(Science Skills) 2.G: Analyze data by identifying significant statistical features.
texasStemStandards: Communication: Students use STEM terminology (Variable Ratio, Dopamine, Probability) to communicate arguments.

brief: 1. Retrieve data sheets from Module 1.
2. Instruction (10 min): How to plot cumulative record graphs.
3. Activity (20 min): Students graph Time (x) vs. Rewards (y).
4. Analysis (10 min): Compare slope and regularity.
5. Discussion: Why does the 'unpredictable' line create more anxiety?
detailed: Review (5 mins): Recap the two simulation rounds (Hard to win vs. Easy to win).
Graphing Instruction (10 mins): Demonstrate how to set up the axes. X-axis = Time (Scroll attempts). Y-axis = Cumulative Tokens (Total rewards).
Execution (15 mins): Students plot both Round 1 and Round 2 data on the same graph using different colors.

Analysis (10 mins): Facilitate a discussion. Show how Round 1 (Variable Ratio) often leads to 'burst' behavior or frustration, whereas Round 2 is steady. Connect this to the 'pull-to-refresh' mechanic in apps.

brief: 1. Get your data sheet from the previous session.
2. Set up your graph: X-axis is 'Time', Y-axis is 'Tokens'.
3. Plot the points for Round 1 in Blue.
4. Plot the points for Round 2 in Red.
5. Compare the lines: Which one looks more like a staircase?
detailed: Step 1: Data Viz. You are converting your raw data into a visual model.
Step 2: Plotting. For every 'scroll' where you got a token, make a mark. Connect the dots. You are creating a 'Cumulative Record'.
Step 3: Comparison. Look at the Blue Line (Low Reward). Notice the long flat lines (no reward) followed by jumps. This represents 'anticipation'.
Step 4: Reflection. Write a brief statement: Why do game designers prefer the 'Blue Line' pattern if they want to keep you playing longer?

trioCompliance.justification: This module fulfills the Math instruction component of UB/UBMS by requiring students to model real-world data using coordinate graphing.

stemConnections.math: Algebra: Slope as a rate of reinforcement.

careerPathways: Game Designer (BS Computer Science / Game Design)
collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

activities.title: Module 3: Unboxing the Black Box (Part 1) - Algorithmic Logic Design
activities.description: Students begin the algorithm unit by learning logical operators and designing the 'weighting' system for a social media feed.
learningObjectives: Understand the logic of sorting algorithms (If/Then/Else).
Assign weighted variables to qualitative data.
teks: (Computer Science I) 4.B: Design and implement algorithms to solve specific problems.
(Algebra I) 2.A: Determine the domain and range of a linear function.
texasStemStandards: Design Process: Students identify a problem (information filtering) and design a solution.

brief: 1. Lecture (15 min): What is an algorithm? (Input -> Process -> Output).
2. Concept (10 min): Weighted Variables. Why is a video worth more than text?
3. Activity (15 min): Groups design their 'Ranking Formula'.
4. Groups assign point values to 'Interests', 'Media Type', and 'Recency'.
detailed: Concept Intro (15 mins): Explain that computers don't have 'opinions'; they have math. Introduce the concept of a 'Weighted Variable'. Example: If (Post == Video) Then (Score = Score + 5).
Group Setup (5 mins): Divide students into Engineering Teams. Give each team a target User Profile (e.g., 'The Gamer', 'The Activist').

Formula Design (20 mins): The teams must write a linear equation to rank content. Example Formula: Total Score = (Topic Match * 5) + (Is_Video * 3) + (Is_Viral * 2). They must justify why they chose those weights.

brief: 1. Learn how code makes decisions using 'If/Then' logic.
2. Review your assigned 'User Profile'. What do they like?
3. Create a formula: How many points is a 'Like' worth? A 'Share'?
4. Write down your team's specific Algorithm Equation.
detailed: Step 1: The Engineer's Mindset. You are coding a bot. The bot needs rules.
Step 2: Assigning Weights. Look at your User. If they love sports, a sports post should get high points. Assign a variable 'S' for Sports match (e.g., S = 10 points).
Step 3: Media Formats. Do you want to push video? If so, make V (Video) worth 5 points and T (Text) worth 1 point.
Step 4: Finalize Formula. Write your equation clearly on paper. You will use this in the next class to rank real cards.

allowableServices: Exposure to Careers in Computer Science
trioCompliance.justification: Focuses on algebraic logic and computer science principles, key components of the UBMS mandate.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Instruction in mathematics and science.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

activities.title: Module 4: Unboxing the Black Box (Part 2) - Calculation & Sorting
activities.description: Students act as the 'CPU', applying their designed formulas to a set of content cards to generate a ranked feed.
learningObjectives: Calculate weighted scores for data sorting.
Execute an algorithm manually to understand processing logic.
teks: (Math Models) 1.C: Select tools to solve problems.
(Computer Science) 4.C: Trace the execution of an algorithm.
texasStemStandards: STEM Content Knowledge: Application of algebraic formulas.

materialsList.item: Index Cards (Content Cards with various topics)

brief: 1. Distribute 'Content Card' decks (10-15 cards per group).
2. Students apply the formula created in Module 3 to each card.
3. Calculation phase (25 min): Math work.
4. Sorting phase (10 min): Arrange cards by score (High to Low).
5. Check work: Verify calculation accuracy.
detailed: Setup (5 mins): Students retrieve their formulas from Module 3. Hand out the 'Content Decks' (mixed posts: news, memes, ads, friends).

Processing (25 mins): This is the 'CPU' phase. Students must calculate the precise score for every card based on their User Profile. Example: Card is 'Sports Video'. Formula: (Sports=10) + (Video=5) = 15. Write '15' on the card.
Sorting (10 mins): Instruct students to stack the cards physically. Highest number on top. This is the 'Feed' the user sees.

brief: 1. Take your deck of Content Cards.
2. Use your Formula to grade every single card.
3. Write the final 'Relevance Score' on the corner of the card.
4. Stack the cards in order: Highest score on top.
5. This stack is your User's 'Feed'.
detailed: Step 1: Processing. You are the processor. Don't use your personal opinion; use the Formula you wrote.
Step 2: Calculation. Use calculators. Be precise. If the algorithm is coded to give +5 for 'Viral', you must add 5, even if you think the post is annoying.
Step 3: The Output. Arrange the cards. The top 3 cards are what the user sees on their screen. The bottom cards are what the algorithm 'hid' from them.

trioCompliance.justification: Strict application of algebraic concepts to solve a problem. Students are performing 'computational thinking' manually.

collegePathways: Associate of Science in Data Science

activities.title: Module 5: Unboxing the Black Box (Part 3) - Bias & Ethics Analysis
activities.description: Students analyze the sorted feeds from Module 4 to identify 'Echo Chambers' and 'Filter Bubbles,' discussing the societal impact of algorithmic sorting.
learningObjectives: Analyze how algorithmic personalization creates confirmation bias.
Evaluate the ethical implications of hidden information.
teks: (Social Studies/Civics) 13.B: Analyze the impact of technology on the political process and society.
texasStemStandards: Societal Impact: Students evaluate how technology impacts society.

brief: 1. Review the top 3 cards vs. bottom 3 cards of each group (10 min).
2. Define 'Filter Bubble' and 'Confirmation Bias' (10 min).
3. Group Rotation (10 min): Look at other groups' feeds.
4. Discussion (10 min): How does this affect democracy/mental health?
detailed: Analysis (10 mins): Ask groups to present their 'Feed'. If the User liked Sports, is their entire feed Sports? What happened to the 'World News' card?
Concept (10 mins): Explain that algorithms maximize engagement, not truth. Define 'Confirmation Bias': seeing only what you already agree with.

Synthesis (20 mins): Have students answer: 'If my user only sees these top 3 cards for a year, what will they believe about the world?' Discuss the ethical responsibility of engineers to code for diversity vs. profit.

brief: 1. Look at the top of your stack. Is it repetitive?
2. Look at the bottom of the stack. What did your user miss?
3. Swap with another group. How is their reality different from yours?
4. Discuss: Is it fair that an equation decides what you see?
detailed: Step 1: The Filter Bubble. Notice that your user is isolated. They are in a bubble of their own interests.

Step 2: Hidden Data. Find the cards with the lowest scores. Imagine these cards contained vital safety information. Why did your formula hide them? (Likely because they weren't 'entertaining' enough).
Step 3: Ethical Engineering. If you were hired by TikTok or Instagram, would you change the code? How would you balance making money (engagement) with keeping people informed?

trioCompliance.justification: Connects STEM skills to critical thinking and societal impact. Essential for developing responsible future scientists/engineers.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Instruction in literature and society (Media Literacy).

careerPathways: Tech Policy Advisor (JD/Master of Public Policy)
collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Political Science

activities.title: Module 6: Digital Wellness (Part 1) - The Geometry of Face Filters
activities.description: Students learn the engineering and geometry behind AR (Augmented Reality) face filters, focusing on mesh mapping and coordinate systems.
learningObjectives: Understand how facial recognition mesh mapping works (computer vision).
Identify the coordinate geometry (X, Y, Z axes) used in AR.
teks: (Geometry) 1.A: Identify and describe the structural features of geometric figures.
(Technology Applications) 6.A: Demonstrate knowledge of current technology terminology and concepts.
texasStemStandards: Inquiry-Based Learning: Students explore the 'how' behind everyday technology.

materialsList.item: Optional: Smartphone with Snapchat/TikTok for demo

brief: 1. Lecture (15 min): Computer Vision & Face Meshes.
2. Visualization (10 min): Show the 468-point landmark map.
3. Activity (15 min): 'Analog Filter' - Drawing geometry on portraits.
4. Explain how changing vector distance changes appearance.
detailed: Tech Theory (20 mins): Explain that computers see faces as a collection of points (vectors). Show a diagram of a Face Mesh. Explain that 'Beauty Filters' work by altering the Euclidean distance between points (e.g., shrinking jaw width, enlarging eye radius).
Analysis (20 mins): Discuss the 'Golden Ratio' mathematically. Ask students to identify which coordinates are changed most often in filters (Cheekbones: X-axis expansion; Chin: Y-axis reduction).

brief: 1. Learn how a camera 'reads' your face using dots.
2. Look at the Face Mesh diagram.
3. Identify the X (horizontal) and Y (vertical) coordinates.
4. Discuss: How does the math of the filter change the shape of the face?
detailed: Step 1: Computer Vision. Understand that to a computer, your face is just a list of numbers (coordinates).
Step 2: The Mesh. Visualize the wireframe grid that overlays your face in real-time.
Step 3: Geometry in Action. If a filter makes your eyes bigger, it is simply increasing the radius of the circle defined by points 33, 133, and 362. It is geometry, not magic.

trioCompliance.justification: This module introduces high-level engineering concepts (Computer Vision/AR) suitable for the Math/Science focus of UBMS.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering
Bachelor of Fine Arts in Digital Media

activities.title: Module 7: Digital Wellness (Part 2) - Statistical Analysis
activities.description: Students conduct a statistical analysis of screen time versus mood, using Excel/Google Sheets to calculate correlation coefficients.
learningObjectives: Analyze scatter plots related to mental health and technology usage.
teks: (Statistics) 4.F: Analyze scatterplots to determine the strength and direction of association.
(Health) 1.F: Analyze the influence of media and technology on health.
texasStemStandards: Real-world issues: Connecting mental health to technology through data.

materialsList.item: Anonymous Data Set (Screen Time vs. Anxiety Score)

brief: 1. Distribute Laptops and Data Set (5 min).
2. Lab (20 min): Input data, create Scatter Plot.
3. Math (10 min): Calculate 'r' (Correlation Coefficient).
4. Wrap-up (5 min): Correlation vs. Causation discussion.
detailed: Data Entry (10 mins): Provide students with a 2-column dataset (X=Hours Scrolled, Y=Anxiety 1-10). Have them type this into the spreadsheet.
Visualization (15 mins): Walk through the menu: Insert > Chart > Scatter Plot. Add Trendline.
Calculation (10 mins): Teach the formula '=CORREL(array1, array2)'. Explain the result (Closer to 1 = Strong Link).
Conclusion (5 mins): Discuss if the phone causes anxiety, or if anxious people use phones more.

brief: 1. Open a blank spreadsheet.
2. Type in the data points provided by the teacher.
3. Create a Scatter Plot chart.
4. Use the CORREL formula to find the math behind the trend.
5. Decide: Is there a link between screen time and mood?
detailed: Step 1: Data Science. You are acting as a data analyst. Input the raw data carefully.
Step 2: Plotting. Create the visual. Look at the slope. Is it going up (Positive correlation)?
Step 3: The R-Value. Calculate the Correlation Coefficient. If r > 0.7, it is a strong correlation.
Step 4: Interpretation. Numbers don't lie, but they can mislead. Does this prove phones are bad? Or just that they are related to bad moods?

trioCompliance.justification: Fulfills the Statistics requirement while addressing permissible mental health/personal counseling topics.
